1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Effective October 2008, sermorelin acetate (Geref(R) Diagnostic) will no longer be available.
  • Growth hormone deficiency: 30 mcg/kg SC daily at bedtime; discontinue when epiphyses are fused
  • Growth hormone deficiency; Diagnosis: after overnight fast, 1 mcg/kg IV over 30 sec

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• geriatric use (patients 65 years of age or olders)
  • growth hormone deficiency secondary to an intracranial lesion

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Sermorelin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Flushing, Sermorelin diagnostic, Injection site reaction, Local pain, swelling, redness
  • Immunologic:Antibody development

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Sermorelin acetate, also called growth releasing hormone (1-29) and growth hormone releasing hormone (1-29), directly stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone (GH), thus increasing plasma GH concentrations.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • diagnostic; reconstitute with accompanying sterile diluent
  • diagnostic; follow with a 3 mL NS flush
  • diagnostic; give in morning following an overnight fast

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: growth hormone deficiency-diagnosis: blood sampling 15 min and immediately prior to injection and at 15-min intervals for up to 1 hr following injection

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause flushing.
  • Patient should fast overnight prior to administration of drug.
